critique: This executive order from 1946 focuses on coordinating federal research activities to strengthen national defense, develop the domestic economy, and increase fundamental knowledge. It establishes the President's Scientific Research Board to advise the Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion. The order emphasizes efficiency and coordination within the government. There's a slight tilt towards expanding executive power through centralized review and direction of research, and a focus on national defense and economic development. There is no mention of immigration or social inclusion. The order seems to favor federal control over research activities.
